courses.description: This course aims to study the relationship between public polices and the values and ethics underlying them. It is the basic contention of this course that the making of public policies cannot be made divorced from moral and political values. These values provide justification for the legitimacy of policies. The course is divided into two parts. The first part introduces some major political theories and theoretical frameworks for students to understand the meaning and importance of values in different moral outlook. Values discussed cover rights and obligation, justice and fair procedure, freedom and democracy, community and citizenship, and the proper relation between personal and social responsibility. The second part focuses on case studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Public Policy
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand how different moral issues arise in the making of public policy.
2. Develop moral framework to analyze and evaluate social policies and public affairs.
3. Understand fundamental concepts and values in moral and political philosophy.
4. Think critically and philosophically in the debates of public policies.
5. Apply moral concepts to analyze public policies.
courses.course_syllabus:
It is the basic contention of this course that the making of public policies cannot be divorced from moral and political values. These values provide justification for the legitimacy of policies. The course is divided into two parts: The first part introduces major political theories and theoretical frameworks for students to understand the meaning and importance of values from different moral perspectives. Values discussed cover rights and obligations, justice and fair procedures, freedom and democracy, community and citizenship, and the proper relation between personal and social responsibilities. The second part focuses on case studies.

* *Course Content**

1. Normative perspective on public policies
2. Theoretical framework: utilitarianism, liberalism, and perfectionism
3. Political theories: universal, comparative, and distributive justice
4. Values and types of different political and governmental systems
5. Values and public sector reforms
6. Values and ethics for public organizations
7. Values and ethics for public policy markers
8. Values and ethics in public policy making
9. Framework and principles for moral evaluation of public policies
10. Ethics and code of conducts for professional practices
11. Public leadership ethics

courses.description: This course focuses on the application of methodological and statistical techniques in conducting policy research, with the objective of sensitizing students to adopt an evidence-based approach to assess public policies and social programs. Course contents include basic concepts in research designs, data collection techniques and statistical analyses. Discussions include both the qualitative and quantitative approaches to evaluate effectiveness, efficiency, and public accountability that define good public policies and social programs. Special attentions are given to the influences of the political environment and the competing interests among stakeholders in the research process. Real-world examples are used to illustrate practical skills in policy research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Public Policy
courses.course_syllabus:
The whole course consists of three parts. The first part introduces the basic elements: research question, theory, research design, and conceptualization. The second part discusses some qualitative methods, including case study, interviews, and content analysis. The final part focuses on quantitative methods: descriptive and inferential analysis, and survey research. For the quantitative part, Microsoft Excel will be used to conduct statistical analysis. The teacher will demonstrate the analysis steps in class where necessary. Students are expected to learn the basic skills of statistical analysis.

This course also highlights the application and implication of methodological and statistical techniques in policy research. Therefore, real-life examples of public policies are discussed in class in order to advance students’ understanding and foster their policy analysis capacity.

courses.title: Public Organization Management
courses.description: Through discussing key questions in public organization theory and public management, the course examines how different aspects of public organizations, including their structure, environment and culture, can have an enormous impact on different stages of policymaking and policy outcomes. Emphasis of the course is on the understanding of the general theoretical frameworks of the field and the ability to apply them to the context of real-world problems and issues. Examples and cases from Hong Kong, China and major Asian and western countries are used for linking up the theory and practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Public Policy
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Obtain knowledge about and discuss critically the changing nature of a selection of theories, trends and international practices in public organization management over the last decade.

2) Recognize and appreciate the concepts and features of public organizations and their behavior and the working environment of an organization while also providing students with a clear understanding of the characteristics of public organizations

3) Participate with current debates about the nature and impact of managerial strategies, tools and practices they may enact to reach public organizations’ objectives and to improve their performance.

4) Discuss key issues and processes entailed in the successful leadership and management of public management change processes while also comparing the different types of organizational changes and summarize its impacts.
courses.course_syllabus:

1) Introduction AND What is Public Organization Management
2) Managing and Measuring Organizational Performance
3) Motivation
4) Communicating Effectively
5) Organizational Culture
6) Decision Making and Ethics
7) Leading and Managing Change
8) Conflict and Stress
9) Formal & Informal Groups in Organizations
10) Leadership, Job Satisfaction, and Turnover
11) Privatization and Outsourcing
12) Financial Resource Management Budgetary Models and NPM
13) Globalization, Diffusion and Performance Management

courses.description: This course examines the political, social and economic importance of NGOs in view of the theoretical discussions derived from a variety of empirical research in the Western countries and the practical experiences faced by NGOs in Hong Kong. The juxtaposition of theory and practice constitutes the major theme of the course. A number of NGOs are to be studied, ranging from interest groups, community groups, social movement organisations, to social service organisations and international NGOs. Emphasis is placed on the manners in which these organisations interact with government, political parties and other social groups in the local and international contexts.

1. To raise students' awareness of the development and importance of NGOs.
2. To enable students to gain a clearer understanding of the character and functions of civil society organizations.
3. To enable students to study the functions and consequences of various types of NGOs.
courses.course_syllabus:

* *5) Management and accountability of NGOs**

* *6) Interest groups: Trade unions in Hong Kong**

* *7) Community-based organisations, participation and social capital**

courses.title: Comparative Public Policy
courses.description: The course objective is to explain policy outcomes of different political units, whether they are national or sub-national governments. The course also discusses some fundamental issues concerning the approach, scope and methods of doing comparative public policy. The course is divided into two parts. First, some foundational concepts, conceptual definitions and the underpinnings of doing comparative public policy will be given. Second, cases in major policy areas including Hong Kong, China and major countries in regions around the world will be examined by applying the concepts and theoretical frameworks introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Public Policy
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understanding more about the conceptual and theoretical dimensions of comparative public policy.
2. Becoming more open-minded and tolerant to different policies with various outcomes and they are different from the local contexts.
3. Ability to integrate empirical findings with theoretical guidance.
4. Working with student-fellows to have team spirit and group efforts.
5. Presentation skills in the class and communication techniques are used.
6. Coordination efforts between student-fellows to present findings and analyse data.
7. Locate the policy debate within the Asian context, guided by a larger theoretical approach.
8. Ability to think critically.
9. Explore policy alternatives to the existing and pressing social issues and problems.
courses.course_syllabus: This course examines the comparative study of the essence, characteristics, structure and process of public policies. The assumption is that through comparative study on countries (regions) based on substantive differences in institutions, different governance styles, developmental stages, and varied political processes that will entail differences for us to learn from each other. Put it simply, comparative public policy is to explain policy outcomes by comparing different political units, whether they are national or sub-national governments. The course offers foundational concepts and approaches in the field of comparative public policy, and begins with an introduction to the concepts of understanding comparative public policy. Questions and issues such as why comparative approach is needed to the study of public policy; What the significances and benefits of doing this are; And how it is conducted comparatively will be tackled, among many others. Then we will focus on a few substantive policies subsequently such as anti-corruption policy, higher educational policy, housing policy, poverty issue and aging policy. All these illustrate and demonstrate the importance, significance and insight drawn from the comparative study of public policy. In short, both conceptual ideas and empirical policies will be studied to enhance our understanding of public policies in a comparative manner. Moreover, practical implications and lessons will be drawn and learned. Last, but not the least, group presentations will be encouraged in the final weeks of the class. The number of groups will depend on the size of the class and the presentations should provide an excellent forum for us to engage in an active mode of discussion. Ideas can be tested; points will be made, and, above all, judgements shall be formed. This will further cultivate a sense of group learning within a productive and an encouraging academic environment.

courses.title: Climate Policy Analysis
courses.description: The course covers a wide range of topics to systematically train students on climate and, more broadly, environmental policy analysis. It starts with an introduction to environmental externalities and the Environmental Kuznets Curve. It then focuses on analytical tools, including environmental valuation, carbon accounting, decomposition analysis, and cost-benefit analysis. The course also explores environmental justice and politics. Various climate/environmental policy instruments will be examined, including environmental impact assessments, voluntary agreements, emission taxes/fees, emission trading, and command and control regulations. The final module focuses on environmental governance, addressing climate change control, and culminates in a mock climate conference. Throughout, the course balances theoretical concepts with practical applications, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of climate policy analysis and environmental governance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Public Policy;or MSSc Government and Politics (Greater China); or MSc in Sustainable Global Business.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes:

* Understand the complexities of climate policy-making processes and their various stakeholders
* Apply analytical tools such as carbon accounting, decomposition analysis, and cost-benefit analysis to climate policy problems
* Critically evaluate the effectiveness of different climate policy instruments
* Analyze and compare climate policies at local, national, and international levels
* Develop skills in writing policy memos and recommendations for improving existing climate policies
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture will be given on the topics as follows:

1. Introduction: Externality, market failure, Environmental Kuznets Curve
2. Valuing the environment: Value of a statistical life, discount rate, hedonic pricing
3. Carbon accounting: ESG, Scope 1, 2, 3 emissions, double counting (decide on your own emissions)
4. Decomposition analysis: Emission inventory, Activity, emission factor, practice decomposition
5. Cost benefit analysis: Rational choice
6. Environmental justice and politics: Pollution heaven and migration, NIMBY, pollution/mitigation burden
7. EIA & voluntary agreements: EIA, SEA; Information disclosure (design your label & let the other group to choose)
8. Emission tax/fee: Environmental tax, fee, subsidy, deposit-refund, Payments for Ecosystem Services
9. Emission trading: Market creation (property rights, cap and trade), Practice trading (record your transactions)
10. Command and control: Mandatory and voluntary compliance, regulations, enforcement and compliance
11. Environmental governance: Goal-centered, rule-based, central planning
12. Control of climate change: Greenhouse gases, climate change, mitigation, energy transition, carbon neutrality; Kyoto Protocol and Paris Agreement
13. Climate conference: Mock Conference of Parties for Climate Negotiation
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students’ feedback on the course will be obtained through course evaluation forms on course content and delivery. Students are also encouraged to air their views during class discussions and through emails.

courses.description: In this course, different theories of planning and urban design are outlined, researched and adapted to current issues in Hong Kong and China. courses.title: Topical Studies in Public Policy II
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of important topics in public policy and government administration. Examples of these topics involve democratic governance, political sociology, social policy & welfare in Hong Kong & East Asia, political & economic transition in China, and program evaluation, etc. The topics of the course may vary according to the area of expertise of the instructor and the interest of the class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Public Policy
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) To acquire basic understandings of a public policy topic or issue.
2) To be able to analyze public policy issues in selected topics.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lectures will be given on the topics as follows:
1) Introduction
2) A systems approach to political environment of public policy
3) Regime Types and Political Systems
4) Political Executives and Political Leaders
5) The Assemblies
6) Political Parties
7) Interest Group and Media
8) The General Public: Changing popular political culture
9) Subnational Politics– Central-Local relations
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are more than welcome to offer comments and suggestions on any aspect of teaching at any time. They may do so by emailing the instructor, one-to-one discussion with the instructor, or group discussion with the instructor. They are also welcome to carefully fill the course evaluation questionnaire and write their comments in the open-ended sections.

Heywood, A. 2002. *Politics*, 2nd Edition, Palgrave Macmillan.

Scott, I. 2010. *The Public Sector in Hong Kong: Government, Policy and People*. Hong Kong, Hong Kong University Press.

Ranney, 1996. *Governing: An Introduction to Political Science*, 7th edition, New Jersey, Prentice-Hall.

Saich, T. 2011. *Governance and Politics of China*, 3rd edition, Palgrave Macmillan.

Wang, J.C.F. 2002. *Contemporary Chinese Politics: An Introduction*, 7th Edition, Prentice-Hall Internation, Inc.
